stories.storyText:
[Code Name] Sussurro
[Gender] Female
[Combat Experience] 1 year
[Place of Birth] Siracusa
[Date of Birth] September 4
[Race] Vulpo
[Height] 142cm
[Infection Status] 
Crystals have appeared on her body. Infection confirmed by medical examination.

[Physical Strength] Normal
[Mobility] Normal
[Physical Resilience] Normal
[Tactical Acumen] Normal
[Combat Skill] Normal
[Originium Arts Assimilation] Normal

Sussurro is a graduate of the Siracusa-Palermo Medical Academy. She has a sufficient level of knowledge in basic medical care.
She is now a medic at Rhodes Island and is a respected member of the headquarters' logistics system.

Imaging tests have shown the outlines of her internal organs to be indistinct due to abnormal shadows. Originium granules have been detected in her circulatory system, confirming her to be infected with Oripathy.

[Cell-Originium Assimilation] 2%
Patient's oripathy is mild and currently shows no indications of spreading.

[Blood Originium-Crystal Density] 0.3u/L
Patient's disease is under control.

Sussurro was born to an ordinary family in a large city in Siracusa. Her parents were ordinary citizens who worked in local public institutions. They had two sons and two daughters. Sussurro was their third child.
Although Sussurro's parents wanted her to be a quiet, obedient child, she did not respond positively to these expectations. Sometimes this was to help her younger sister get back snacks her brothers had stolen, and sometimes this was to help her sister get a hold of a toy she couldn't have. Since her childhood, Sussurro has developed a personality that takes initiative.
Sussurro's two older brothers have already grown up and have gone into business. Her younger sister is studying in kindergarten. Sussurro herself chose to study medicine. She did not do so out of any grand ambition or dream, but because the medical industry in Siracusa holds promise and is a good field to work in.

Sussurro's life as a medical student was uneventful. She busied herself preparing for exams and participating in experiments. Her small figure was often bouncing between the different buildings on campus, and her short stature notwithstanding, all of her abilities steadily progressed.
Luckily for Sussurro, she got to make a solid group of friends between classes and maintained good relationships with some older students. These medical students all embraced the same dreams, confronted the same challenges, and worked towards the future together. With everyone's help and encouragement, Sussurro managed to press on through the long, dull days in her time as a medical student.
Though Sussurro originally had no aspirations of her own, through making friends with all kinds of people, she gradually came to understand the reasoning behind their choices. Whether it was to secure a job with a stable salary and life environment, out of a genuine desire to help others, or just out of pure interest in biology, Sussurro found their aspirations infectious. She liked everyone who had a dream and worked hard to fulfill it, and at the same time, her own thinking became clear:
Does becoming a doctor hold any special meaning for me?

When the oripathy crisis gradually worsened throughout every major city, people were forced to confront an all-new and unknown illness. Now, both public and private hospitals were packed with patients, and medical resources became strained. Sussurro's clinical instructor as well as her seniors all participated in efforts to combat the disease.
Faced with a notice that all major hospitals were recruiting medical students to act as volunteers, Sussurro did not think twice about signing up. It was at this moment that she felt she was finally a medical student, and she found genuine purpose.

Sussurro did not think about the fact that she had become infected by volunteering to participate in the treatment of the infected. Even when three days had passed since she herself had been transformed from doctor to infected, she did not feel anything. Everything just seemed to happen so suddenly.
It wasn't until she witnessed a patient be declared untreatable and get sent to the intensive care unit with a blank stare that she made the connection between herself and the situation at hand.

skins.description:
An outfit commonly worn by Operators.
While not as practical as a uniform, it's what they find most comfortable.

An outfit that has been improved after the Operator's Promotion.
Custom-made to suit each Operator's experiences and needs, these outfits are designed to provide them maximum flexibility on any battlefield. Furthermore, this is all done without compromising the comfort that they've come to expect.
<color name=#ffffff>MARTHE [Coral Coast] Summer Flowers Series FA026. Brings out a girl's figure and physique using all-natural materials. Pursue this summer's hottest trend.</color>

<color name=#ffffff>Cambrian 1100 Winter New Arrivals/Travel Freely. A red and white baseball jacket over a black hoodie, paired with drawstring pants and sports shoes. Comfy and casual, unrestrictive and lightweight, suited for day-to-day travel.</color>

skills.desc:
ATK <@ba.vup>+{atk:0%}</>, ASPD <@ba.vup>+{attack_speed}</>
<@ba.rem>Can be used up to twice in one battle</>

modules.desc:
Operator Sussurro has demonstrated a remarkable aptitude for healing teammates in the field.
The Field Operations Department has thus passed the following resolution:
This operator shall be appointed a Medic Operator during field operations to exercise Medic responsibilities.
In witness whereof,
This badge is hereby conferred upon the above named.

Based on my grasp of the situation, the Originium crystals present on the Infected by all rights shouldn't be active. The professor and student mentors haven't shown any symptoms—which is to say, ordinary contact with an Infected, and even treatment of them, likely doesn't lead to infection at all.
Which lets me confirm that I was only infected because I made contact with Originium while it was in an active state.
As for the active Originium's origins: Was this region already polluted by Originium?—Unlikely, because the professor and student mentors weren't infected. Was it my contact with Infected blood?—Not impossible.
I can be sure that Infected blood carries traces of active Originium. If so, I need to distinguish whether the areas I contacted at the time were open wounds, how long the contact lasted, the freshness of contacted blood, etc. For all factors.
If there was a wound, fresh blood was contacted, and contact was prolonged, I can hypothesize resultant infection was inevitable; if there was a wound, stale blood was contacted, and contact was brief, would infection occur? This can determine whether or not Originium activity in the blood of Infected wanes as time passes. Also, if there was no wound and fresh blood was contacted; if there was no wound, stale blood was contacted...
Unfortunately, I don't remember the exact circumstances. Actually, I don't even know how I was infected. I was too busy...
But I do remember that before I discovered Originium crystals on my body, I had a fever, headaches, and other symptoms. Right, I was under the impression for a few days that I'd fallen ill from overwork. Now I see it must have been a sort of initial onset of the Oripathy infection. I often hear patients give similar accounts of their own circumstances during diagnosis.
Plus, given a view informed by the critical care of Infected over the past days, my own condition is relatively mild, but I can't be sure of anything without further tests.
That's the best summary I can give for now. If I think of anything else later, I'll add it here.
The professor and mentors are staying here to continue their assignments. Aside from providing some practical accounts of Infected life from the perspective of a doctor, I'm not much help anymore. I'm currently searching for a medical organization that specializes in researching and treating Oripathy. As volunteers in the face of this still-unknown disease, we can't provide very effective care to those who need it most, and there may even be further infections down the line. We need more specialized, in-depth research before we can confront this sickness.
Would such an organization exist?
—Sussurro's diary entry following Oripathy diagnosis

voice_lines.voiceText: Time for a break, Doctor. Just how long have you been sitting at a table like that? Get up and go stretch out a little. Yes, I mean now.

It is my duty to perform regular check-ups on Oripathy patients. Some are personable enough, but a few are hard to communicate with. It's not the first time, though, so worry not, they will understand how vital a doctor is to them.
You know what an amnesia patient should pay attention to, Doctor? Don't work yourself into the ground. Work and relaxation are equally important!
You always have patients who ignore the doctor's orders, but in battle, you don't see a doctor who'd miss a single cry for help.

The advancement of medicine is a lesson taught by none other than the cruelty of war and disasters, a lesson we medical workers learn through pain and suffering... But... It's a fact I figured out long ago. As long as I can help my patients get their lives back, I'm ready to face the fact.
Together we've spent some... uh, I mean, some most memorable moments! Come on, you know I'm not good at this, Doctor. And next time I see you put up that teasing face, I'd be real mad!
Here's a pen. How did I know you wanted it? Well, I've been working with you for a while now, isn't it natural I picked up on it?
I'm still far below the level of Silence and Shining, but that doesn't mean I can't overcome an obstacle when I see one before me. Otherwise, how can I measure up to your confidence in me?

The sun's good on the deck, and the wind's just fine… Mm? No, I'm not slacking off. It's just... I'm feeling swamped right now, like you occasionally do, Doctor. So, anything bothering you? Mm-hm, keep it as a whisper if it's easier for you this way. I'm listening.
Who came up with this meal plan? I'm having spasms in my stomach just by looking at the list!

Sussurro, Medic, reporting in with a little reminder for the Doctor. Now, I understand you have a lot on your plate, and even if they say a 'doctor' makes the worst patient, you need to follow our advice.
I must make more copies of these battle notes for Myrrh and company.
Promotion ceremony, while everyone stares at me? I don't have to make any embarrassing speeches, do I? No, no, I'm not nervous at all, really...

For this promotion, I have the entire Medical Department to thank, who's been supporting me all the time with their hard work. And of course, thank you too, Doctor, for your guidance. I'm very, very grateful to you all!
Don't worry, I'll watch over them.
Hold everything! You must complete all pre-battle physical exams to deploy!
Attention, medics, make sure to follow all standard procedures in battle. Now, to your positions.
Safety first, and do not touch anything that may be suspicious or infected!
I'm over here!
Speak louder! It's hard to hear over the battle!
Medic's here! Here!
Anybody hurt?
Don't worry, you'll be okay in no time!
Don't concern yourself with fighting, you're still wounded!
Listen to the doctor!
Scream if you're in pain, don't hold it in!
Finally, the battle's over. You should take a break too. I imagine commanding the mission would take a toll on your body.
No casualty on our side. The Doctor's leadership is indeed unparalleled.
Will the enemy return? There are still wounded unable to move here.
Make way, make way! Stop crowding! Wounded coming through!
Promise you'll rest when it's time to, okay?
Um…
Phew. I need a drink after work! Mind handing me a juice, Doctor? Thanks!
Arknights.

Happy New Year, Doctor. New Year's is a time for proper relaxation, and you can't overstress yourself. I know you'll be at the dining table soon, though, and you can't let yourself go too much. I remember how bad your indigestion was after you overate last year. I'll keep an eye on you this time!
How do you do, Doctor.

Doctor, happy birthday. I made you a cylinder cake—they seem popular lately. You don't need to hide it, I figured you'd be rolling in cakes today long beforehand... Anyway, don't eat too much, whatever you do! Watch your sugar intake!

I don't know how much longer life will carry on like this. Sometimes I even feel like I can't make out the future ahead, but if it even gets to us medics, how much worse must it be for our patients, waiting for us to treat them? I'm sure we'll see the light of dawn one day, Doctor.

building_skills.desc: When this Operator is assigned to be the Trainer in the Training Room, <@cc.kw>Medic</> Operators' Specialization training speed <@cc.vup>+30%</>
When this Operator is assigned to the Workshop to process <@cc.kw>elite material</>, the production rate of byproduct increases by <@cc.vup>80%</>
